text: Normally in Julia, you should not be thinking in terms of pointers or references. Just put your thing in the dictionary, then Julia's compiler will figure out if the right thing to do is to put a copy of the thing into the dictionary, or a pointer to the thing

elements.text: Normally in Julia, you should not be thinking in terms of pointers or references. Just put your thing in the dictionary, then Julia's compiler will figure out if the right thing to do is to put a copy of the thing into the dictionary, or a pointer to the thing

text:
Like in this code:
```julia> d = Dict(1=>"hello", 2=>"world")
Dict{Int64,String} with 2 entries:
  2 => "world"
  1 => "hello"

julia> v = [d[1], d[2]]
2-element Array{String,1}:
 "hello"
 "world"```
, I have taken the values of d and put them into the array v.

elements.text: Like in this code:

  2 => "world"
  1 => "hello"

julia> v = [d[1], d[2]]

 "hello"
 "world"
